messages: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:16): in Apple's <video> proposal, does anyone else think availabledurationchange event seems like a progress event?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:17): it seems a bit redundant to me
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:18): it's different from a progress event
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:18): Content-Length is not equal to the duration...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:19): it'd be good to have usecases instead of a spec
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (12:19): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: looks more like something for cuemarks, but I might be wrong
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:27): <keygen> should prolly be added to HTML5...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:28): but I think I already said that once on the list...
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (12:28): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the old Netscape thing noone ever used?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:29): sites rely on it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:29): (it's also in Mozilla)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:29): for IE they use some ActiveX control

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:30): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, have you found any documentation that describes exactly what it does and how to use it?  There seems to be very little information about it, which is why it hasn't been added
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:31): it isn't supported by IE either, so browsers really don't need to support it to be compatible with the web
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:32): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, ever heard of sniffing?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:32): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, Skandiabanken relies on it for instance
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:32): what is that site?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:33): I think so. (This information was passed to me.)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:33): there's still the problem of figuring out exactly what it does, how it works and how to use it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:36): yup
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:36): but that should be doable
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:37): aren't https and TLS better solutions for whatever its usecases are?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:40): i don't think so
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:40): then what does it do?  I thought it was to provide some sort of encryption and security
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:41): it generates a key I believe...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:41): for what purpose?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:41): what good is a key if it doesn't fit into any locks?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:41): as I said, I'm not up in the details of what exactly it does
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:41): i just know it's needed
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:41): for one site?  I don't think so
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:43): i would assume more sites use it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:43): it's not that we added it just for them...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:43): does Opera support it?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:44): yes, Opera and Firefox and maybe Safari
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:44): oh, then whoever implemented it there should be able to provide some description of what it does and how it works
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:45): when you submit a form that contains it it starts an async process that generates a key
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:45): in firefox it's just that and in Opera you can encrypt this key using a master password

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:46): I have a general idea of what happens on the client side before form submission.  It's just that I do not understand what use it is to the server or the client afterwards
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:46): http://webdesign.about.com/od/htmltags/p/bltags_keygen.htm
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:47): so Safari supports it as well
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:50): so presumably, servers are supposed to be able to encrypt data using that public key and send it back to the browser
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:51): in WebKit it subclasses the <select> element
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:53): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e - <keygen> and browser support for it sounds potentially very useful to me
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:53): is it meant for client-side signing of data/documents?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:54): the usecase isn't entirely clear to me
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:54): well, the lack of a standard mechanism for digital signing in browsers is on thing that causes browser lock-in in some places
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:54): i just know it's supported in some form of interop between Safari / Firefox / Opera
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:54): in Korea, for example
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:54): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e - OK
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:56): anway, Korean banks and government sites use digital signing quite a lot, but they rely on an ActiveX control for doing it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:56): without any fallback or alternative mechanism for other browsers
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:56): http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2005-November/thread.html#5092
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:56): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, I see, I guess that might indeed be the usecase for <keygen> ...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:57): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e - maybe
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:58): I just glanced at the old Netscape docs you cited and it's not really clear from those what the use case is meant to me
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:58): to be

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:58): if that's its usecase, and it actually works like that, then it could be useful.  But there's not much point discussing it till we find out exactly how it's supposed to work.

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:59): 

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:59): 

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:59): 

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:59): 
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:59): http://www.blooberry.com/indexdot/html/tagpages/k/keygen.htm
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:59): aargh!, sorry, my clipboard was full of other stuff I didn't realise :-(
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:00): anyway, that crap I pasted was the output of the keygen element
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:02): Safari only supports keytype and challenge
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:02): (and only RSA)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:04): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e - maybe Hallvord and write up a description of what it's actually being used for in practice (whatever the Skandiabanken is using it for) and send it to the list
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:05): s/Hallvord and/Hallvord can/
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:09): this page http://wp.netscape.com/eng/security/downloadcert.html seems to describe the certificates used for it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:32): fancy
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:32): the BBC guys weigh in
b406b22e31ce6e541c3754a7214cec1c (13:34): Just noticed that Sweden's largest auction site allows arbitrary HTML in the object description :S Just alerted my own cookie
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:34): heh
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:41): oh, nice!  I wonder if BBC are considering releasing their content in DRM-free Dirac in the future?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:42): last I read, they were considering implementing DRM and moving to proprietary formats
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:42): if browsers all support their open format...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:42): that would be awesome!
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:42): here it is http://defectivebydesign.org/blog/939
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:43): has Dirac been vetted for patent avoidance in the UK or also in the US?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:44): Thomas' email said "So this time next year, there is a good chance that Dirac will be an international, royalty-free SMPTE standard."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:45): hmm. I wonder how the SMPTE deals with having just approved Microsoft's stuff that is subject to an MPEG-LA portfolio
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:45): that is, how they deal with standardizing something else without upsetting MS too much
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:47): I hope that other "year" it takes is a realistic estimate
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:52): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, someone just raised that question
b406b22e31ce6e541c3754a7214cec1c (13:53): sent them a mail, I hope they fix it soon
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:02): does Dirac need to be embedded in a container format like Ogg to be used?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:03): prolly
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:04): http://dirac.sourceforge.net/
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:06): http://wiki.xiph.org/index.php/OggDirac
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:06): If Direc is better than Theora, than the spec should change to require it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:06): Dirac isn't finished
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:07): see my remark about "year" above
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:07): yeah, I realise that
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:07): I wonder if the Dirac folks are able and willing to adopt the MPL 1.1 / GPL 2.0 / LGPL 2.1 tri-license...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:08): Maybe the spec could recommend both and then let the market decide which is better
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:09): if it's done in a year it prolly make sense to use it
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:09): I thoght the MPL was the tri-licence
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:10): no
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:10): Gecko is tri-licensed
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:10): I'm reading the the MPL FAQ
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:10): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: their FAQ implies that they are using the tri-license after all. (I haven't checked their source headers)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:10): their being Dirac

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:12): "We intend to pack the Dirac elementary stream into MXF, which has lots of useful features. That doesn't preclude it packing into Ogg (or Matroska, or anything else) as well, and it's probably a good idea to have a variety of packing formats. For this the elementary stream needs to be very well defined."

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:12): ok, I get it now.  MPL is one of the 3 licences, which places additional restrictions that are incompatible with GPL.  The tri-license says you have the right to use the code under the terms of either licence
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:17): I wonder if Dirac could be implemented on Rockbox or iPodLinux.  I read somewhere that Theora can't be due to memory and/or processing contstraints
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (14:20): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: is it that bad? Rockbox has support for MPEG on players without video decoder circuitry (on the ipod nano, for instance)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:20): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: the technical problem with avoiding the base techniques of the MPEG family is that the hardware DSP chips accelerate the operations needed for MPEG
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:22): so are you saying that since Dirac won't have the hardware support like MPEG, then it's unlikely?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I am saying that existing MPEG-oriented hardware probably won't be particularly useful for accelerating Theora or Dirac
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:24): (but then, some DSP chips really suck. on Nokia 770, MPEG-4 ASP decoding works better on the CPU than on the DSP)
